alternative_title: Find out what can happen if a child uner the age of 10 breaks the law.
body:
$!Children under 10 who break the law are treated differently to adults or youths under 18 who commit a criminal offence.$!

Children under 10 cannot be charged with committing a criminal offence. However, they can be given a:

- Local Child Curfew
- Child Safety Order

Children under 10 who break the law regularly can sometimes be [taken into care](/what-is-care-order/overview "If your child is taken into care"), or their [parents could be held responsible](/if-my-child-gets-in-trouble-with-police "What happens to me if my child gets in trouble with the police").

##Local Child Curfew

The police can ban children from being in a public place between 9pm and 6am, unless accompanied by an adult. This is called a Local Child Curfew and can last for up to 90 days.

If a child breaks their curfew, they can be given a Child Safety Order.

##Child Safety Order

If a child has committed an offence or broken a Local Child Curfew, they can be placed under the supervision of a [youth offending team](/youth-offending-team "Youth offending teams"). This is called a Child Safety Order.

The order normally lasts for up to 3 months, but in some cases it can last for up to 12 months.

If a child doesn't stick to the rules of an order, the court can consider if the child should be [taken into care](/what-is-care-order/overview "If your child is taken into care").
overview: Children under 10 who break the law can be given a Local Child Curfew, a Child Safety Order or can be taken into care
title: What happens if a child under 10 breaks the law?
